thread.title: SA Government considers security camera boost after concrete slab thrown at car
thread.title_full: SA Government considers security camera boost after concrete slab thrown at car

title: SA Government considers security camera boost after concrete slab thrown at car
text:
SA Government considers extra security cameras at Southern Expressway Updated February 06, 2017 09:25:27 Map: Adelaide 5000 
Extra security surveillance on Adelaide's Southern Expressway is being considered after a large piece of concrete was thrown at a car being driven by a heavily pregnant woman, the State Government has said. 
The car was travelling south between Beach Road and Honey Pot Road when the incident occurred about 1:00am on Sunday. 
The woman was not physically injured, but her car was extensively damaged. 
Police searched the area, but were unable to find the offenders. 
About an hour before the incident, an object was also thrown at another car from the Majors Road overpass. 
Transport Minister Stephen Mullighan said the Government was looking into whether new security cameras and greater rewards should be brought in to tackle such crimes. 
"We've found CCTV can be really effective from deterring people from engaging in this sort of behaviour, it provides not only a good deterrent but if someone does engage in this sort of behaviour it provides sound evidence which can help us prosecute people," he said. 
"[Police] take this matter extremely seriously given the damage that was caused to the victim's car and the potential threat to that person's life. 
"The last thing we want is for people not to feel safe out on our roads because of this sort of behaviour." 
After a series of rock-throwing incidents in 2005, the State Government increased rewards to $50,000 for information leading to the conviction of culprits. 
It also increased penalties aimed at rock throwers. 
A new offence of throwing a missile at a moving vehicle, which attracts a maximum penalty of five years' imprisonment, was introduced, even if there was no damage or consequences.
